descript.abstract: The U.S. Geological Survey's Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center (UMESC) has obtained historical photography of the Upper Mississippi River, collected by the Corps of Engineers. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's (FWS) Upper Mississippi National Wildlife and Fish Refuge contracted the Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center (UMESC) to scan and georeference the 1947 images for lower Pool 8, to create reference images for use in geographic information system (GIS). These data are also distributed through the UMESC Web site, so others can also access the data.
descript.purpose: The Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center administers the Long Term Resource Monitoring Program (LTRMP), authorized under the Water Resources Development Act of 1986 (Public Law 99-662). The mission of the LTRMP is to provide decision-makers with information to maintain the Upper Mississippi River System (UMRS) as a viable large river ecosystem given its multiple-use character. The long-term goals of the Program are to understand the system, determine resource trends and impacts, develop management alternatives, manage information, and develop useful products. The collection and distribution of high-resolution aerial photography aids the Center in meeting these goals.
descript.supplinf: To make the data easier to download, the photo mosaic has been compressed and is being served as a georeferenced MrSid image. A software program that contains MrSid image support or a MrSid image viewer is required to view these data. A free image viewer capable of subsetting, resampling, and exporting the compressed image to georeferenced TIFF image (a .tif image and a .tfw world file) is available at http://www.lizardtech.com/. The data are stored in a Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) projection, zone 15. Two datum options are available, North American Datum 1927 (NAD27) and North American Datum 1983 (NAD83).

idinfo.accconst: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty has been expressed or implied regarding the individual use of the data or aggregate use with other data, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from a U.S. Geological Survey server and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein

idinfo.datacred: US Army Corps of Engineers Upper Mississippi River Restoration- Environmental Management Program -- Long Term Resource Monitoring Program element and USGS's Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center
idinfo.native: Environment as of Metadata Creation: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 10.2 (Build 3552) Service Pack [N/A] (Build [N/A])

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: The horizontal positional accuracy is tested by visual comparison of the data on-screen with existing data sets that cover the same area. The basemap used to register the photos was a digital orthophoto quadrangle.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

procstep.procdesc: GIS interns placed each photograph in a scanner with the photo's most northerly side directed upwards. The photos were scanned using a 200 dots per inch (dpi) image resolution, and the files were saved as TIFF images. The photo image was assigned a name that described the photo's (1) flight line, (2) photo number, (3) the year in which the photo was collected, and (4) a distinction between true color and color infrared.

Each photo was georeferenced using Image Analyst 1.0 Extension for ArcView 3.2. The base imagery in all cases was either 1:12,000 DOQ images or 1:24,000 DRG data. Root mean square (RMS) errors under 7.0 were desired for all areas.
a photo mosaic was created using MrSID Geospatial Encoder 1.4.

stdorder.fees: None. No fees are applicable for obtaining the data set.
